revision.comment: /* top */ Reword intro, so as not to make it sound like they were killed at the start of their mission training
revision.text:
{{Infobox astronaut |name = Elliot M. See Jr. |othername = Elliot McKay See Jr. |image = Elliot See.jpg |type = [[NASA]] [[Astronaut]] |status = Deceased |nationality = [[United States|American]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1927|07|23}} |birth_place = [[Dallas, Texas]], U.S. |death_date = {{Death date and age|1966|02|28|1927|07|23}} |death_place = [[St. Louis, Missouri]], U.S. |resting_place = Arlington National Cemetery {{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/emsee.htm|title=Elliott M. See, Jr., Commander, United States Navy Reserve|website=Arlington National Cemetery|access-date=June 25, 2016}} |alma_mater = [[University of Texas at Austin|UT Austin]]
[[United States Merchant Marine Academy|USMMA]], B.S. 1949
[[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]], M.S. 1962 |occupation = [[Test pilot]], [[engineer]],
[[naval aviator]] |selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#1962|1962 NASA Group 2]] |mission = None |rank = [[Commander (United States)|Commander]], [[United States Naval Reserve|USNR]] |time = |insignia = }} '''Elliot McKay See Jr.''' (July 23, 1927{{spaced ndash}} February 28, 1966) was an [[United States|American]] [[engineer]], [[United States naval aviator|naval aviator]], [[test pilot]], and [[NASA]] [[astronaut]], selected in the [[Astronaut Group 2|second group of astronauts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/see-em.html|title=Astronaut Bio: Elliot M. See Jr.|website=NASA Johnson Space Center|date=February 1966|accessdate=October 9, 2016}} Chosen as the prime command pilot for what would have been his first space flight, [[Gemini 9]], he was killed with his crewmate [[Charles Bassett]] in a 1966 NASA trainer jet crash at the [[St. Louis, Missouri]] [[McDonnell Aircraft]] plant, where they were to take two weeks of [[space rendezvous]] simulator training. ==Biography== ===Early life and education=== See was born in [[Dallas, Texas]] on July 23, 1927, and attended [[Highland Park High School (University Park, Texas)|Highland Park High School]], from which he graduated in 1945. See was active in the [[Boy Scouts of America]] and earned the rank of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]].{{cite web|url=http://www.scouting.org/FILESTORE/pdf/02-558.pdf|title=Astronauts and the BSA|access-date=June 25, 2016|website=Boy Scouts of America}} After initially attending [[University of Texas at Austin|The University of Texas]] where he was a member of [[Phi Kappa Psi]] fraternity. He then attended the [[United States Merchant Marine Academy]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in 1949. He later obtained a [[Master of Science]] degree in [[Engineering]] from [[UCLA]] in 1962. He was married to Marilyn Denahy See, and had three children: Sally, born in 1956; Carolyn, born in 1957; and David, born in 1962.{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautsmemorial.org/elliot-m-see-jr-honored.html |title=Elliot M. See Jr. |website=[[Astronauts Memorial Foundation|The Astronauts Memorial Foundation]], The Center for Space Education |accessdate=October 9, 2016}} ===Navy service, General Electric and NASA career=== [[File:Astronaut Group 2 - S62-6759.jpg|left|thumb|Elliot See (standing row, left) with fellow "New Nine" astronauts]] {{quote box|width=30%|quote='''"Overwhelmed isn't the right word. I was amazed and certainly pleased. It's a very great honor."'''|salign=right|source=â€” See's feelings about being selected as an astronaut{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OL7BCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT58&lpg=PT58&dq=Overwhelmed+isn%27t+the+right+word.+I+was+amazed+and+certainly+pleased.+It%27s+a+very+great+honor.&source=bl&ots=ACeMbRT5po&sig=wDgEnnjt3sd48ejAwr5A9THbSxQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiuqvKgxcbNAhUQzGMKHfy7BjgQ6AEIHjAA#v=onepage&q=Overwhelmed%20isn't%20the%20right%20word.%20I%20was%20amazed%20and%20certainly%20pleased.%20It's%20a%20very%20great%20honor.&f=false|title=Fallen Astronauts: Heroes Who Died Reaching for the Moon, Revised Edition|last1=Burgess|first1=Colin|last2=Doolan|first2=Kate|isbn=978-0803262126|publisher=Bibson Books|date=October 1, 2003|access-date=June 26, 2016}}}} He worked for [[GE Aviation|General Electric]] before and after serving as a [[United States Naval Aviator|Naval Aviator]] from 1953 to 1956. He served as a project pilot for the J79-8 engine development program used in the [[F4H]] aircraft. See conducted [[Aircraft engine|powerplant]] flight tests on the [[General Electric J47|J-47]], [[General Electric J73|J-73]], [[J-79]], [[General Electric CJ805|CJ805]], and CJ805 [[turbofan|aft-fan]] engines. This work involved flying in [[F-86]], [[Douglas F4D Skyray|XF4D]], [[F-104]], [[Grumman F11F-1F Super Tiger|F11F-1F]], [[RB-66]], F4H, and [[Northrop T-38 Talon|T-38]] aircraft. He has logged more than 3,900 hours flying time, including more than 3,300 hours in [[jet aircraft]]. In 1962, See was selected to be one of the new nine NASA astronauts. He served as backup pilot for [[Gemini 5]] and was a [[Capsule communicator|CAPCOM]] in [[Houston]] during the [[Gemini 7]]/[[Gemini 6A|6A]] [[Space rendezvous|rendezvous]] mission in December 1965. He was in line to fly as prime crew Pilot (second seat) for [[Gemini 8]], but was promoted to be the Command Pilot (first seat) of [[Gemini 9]].{{cite book|title=Deke! U.S. Manned Space: From Mercury to the Shuttle |last1=Slayton |first1=Donald K. "Deke" |authorlink1=Deke Slayton |last2=Cassutt |first2=Michael |authorlink2=Michael Cassutt |year=1994 |edition=1st |publisher=[[Forge Books|Forge]] ([[St. Martin's Press]]) |location=[[New York City|New York]] |isbn=0-312-85503-6 |oclc=29845663 |lccn=94-2463}}{{rp|138,168}} According to chief astronaut [[Deke Slayton]]'s autobiography, Slayton did not assign See to Gemini 8 because he did not consider him physically capable of performing an [[extravehicular activity]]. Slayton further stated that he assigned See to Gemini 9 because he had become "sentimental" about getting him a flight.{{rp|167,168}} ===Death=== {{main|1966 NASA T-38 crash}} [[File:The Original Gemini 9 Prime Crew - GPN-2000-001352.jpg|thumb|left|Elliot See and [[Charles Bassett]]]] See and fellow astronaut [[Charles Bassett]], assigned as Pilot for [[Gemini 9]], were killed before their mission on February 28, 1966, when their [[T-38 Talon|T-38]] trainer jet crashed into [[McDonnell Aircraft]] Building 101, known as the McDonnell Space Center, located 1,000 feet (300 m) from [[Lambert Field]] airport in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. Building 101 was where the Gemini spacecraft was built, and they were going there to do [[space rendezvous|rendezvous]] training for two weeks in a simulator, along with their backup crew. See and Bassett died within 500 feet (150 m) of their spacecraft. Both were buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/cabasset.htm|title=Charles Arthur Bassett II |access-date=October 9, 2016|website=Arlington National Cemetery}}{{cite news |first=W. Pate |last=McMichael |work=[[St. Louis Magazine]] |location=[[St. Louis, MO]] |title=Losing The Moon |url=http://www.stlmag.com/St-Louis-Magazine/May-2006/Losing-The-Moon/ |date=May 2006 |accessdate=October 9, 2016}} A [[NASA]] investigative panel later concluded that [[pilot error]] caused by poor visibility due to bad weather had been the principal cause of the accident. The panel concluded that See was flying too low to the ground during his second approach, probably as a result of the poor visibility. Slayton would later express doubts about See's flying ability, claiming that See flew too slowly and "wasn't aggressive enough." The mission was launched three months later, in early June, as [[Gemini 9A]]. The shuffling of the Gemini prime and backup crew assignments that occurred after the deaths of See and Bassett impacted the crew selections for some of the early Apollo manned missions. ==Organizations== See was a member of the [[Society of Experimental Test Pilots]], and an associate [[fellow]] of the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]]. ==Legacy== [[File:Gemini_5_Elliot_See_water_egress_training.jpg|thumb|Elliot during water egress training.]] *See's name is listed on the [[Space Mirror Memorial]], as well as on the [[Fallen Astronaut]] plaque placed on the [[Moon]] by [[Apollo 15]].{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautsmemorial.org/space-mirror-memorial.html|title=The Astronauts Memorial Foundation Space Mirror Memorial|access-date=October 9, 2016|website=The Astronauts Memorial Foundation}}{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/there-is-a-sculpture-on-the-moon-commemorating-fallen-astronauts-358909/?no-ist|title=There Is a Sculpture on the Moon Commemorating Fallen Astronauts|date=January 7, 2013|last1=Eveleth|first1=Rose|website=Smithsonian|access-date=October 9, 2016}} *See was honored as a Distinguished Alumnus of Highland Park High School in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.hpaa.org/distinguished_alumni.html |title=Highland Park High School Distinguished Alumni List |accessdate=May 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120913041952/http://www.hpaa.org/distinguished_alumni.html |archivedate=September 13, 2012}} *A family-approved account of See's life and career appears in the 2003 book ''Fallen Astronauts'' by space historians [[Colin Burgess (author)|Colin Burgess]] and Kate Doolan. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Navy}} *[[List of spaceflight-related accidents and incidents]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book |authorlink1=Codex Regius (author) |last1=Codex Regius |year=2014 |title=The Forgotten Astronauts:A rarely told Chapter of American Spaceflight History|location=[[Wiesbaden]]|publisher=[[CreateSpace]] |isbn=1-4996-1012-2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.astronautix.com/astros/see.htm Astronautix biography of Elliot See] {{NASA Astronaut Group 2}} {{US Navy navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:See, Elliot}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:1966 deaths]] [[Category:American astronauts]] United States]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Missouri]] [[Category:Space program fatalities]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:Eagle Scouts]]
